text: Hey Jon, how are holding up with the whole corona virus thing going on? Did you menage to export the shot okay and send it off?

Morning Rob, I'm good. Self isolating with a sore throat - no idea if its COVID-19 or not! How are you doing? Working from home I hope...
Mirror exported as EXRs and shared on my gmail drive on Friday - no emails so far saying there's anything wrong so I'm keeping my head down and assuming they're happy.

Bit of a cheeky ask but found this the other day on my endless quest to understand projections in Nuke... what do you think? <https://www.mp4fm.com/courses/camera-projection-boot-camp-overview>
The monkey shot is throwing up all sorts of challenges... and I'm a sucker for Nuke courses!

attachments.title: Camera Projection Boot Camp
attachments.text: In this Course, Garrett Fry teaches the latest Camera Projection techniques used in Major Visual Effect Studios by Matte Painters and Environment Artists. This course is for both beginners and seasoned artists. You will learn core camera projection principles and then we apply these principles in progressively advanced exercises and assignments.

text: looks like a great course, I'd even be interested in doing it myself. Got to be honest though its quite expensive.
Yup agreed it is pretty pricey. Been mulling it over for a while since I found it. Watching the free content to see if I can fill in the gaps!
I might watch some of them later on to get a feel for the course. Its quite hard to find advanced knowledge on projections from what I've found.
by the way, they asked us to share this podcast link
<https://www.accessvfx.org/podcast>
Ha ha ha! Watching it now. So badly want a job rn! And to finish that monkey shot!
Thank you!
the worst thing is, I think with all productions taking a break, I have a bad feeling this will delay some vfx work in the long run
by the way, did you have other roto work to put in your showreel?
I think you might be right about a stall in work that may come - seriously uncertain time rn.

I think it's pretty uncertain for everyone, but literally every hollywood production is taking a months break, which will have a knock off effects. Especially if you are freelance, they will pencil you in, and delay the pencil til the shots come in, which is what happened to me when I worked on Blackmirror at Glassworks. They delayed me by 2 weeks from memory, which was 2 weeks without work

But you're a staffer at Framestore rn though right? You prob can't say but I'm guessing a big studio like that is pretty secure and has work plugged in for months in advance. Hopefully the government will step up in any worse case scenarios but hope vfx won't get to that stage... so many of us trying to get that first job!

NO rush on this but I've hit a tricky wall on my monkey shot I need to resolve. I'll probably have to figure it out on my own as it's pretty tricky explain but  I wonder what your first thoughts are (when you have time)...

The thing with Framestore is, most of us are usually only on 3 month contracts, then when they know they have enough work coming up, they renew us for a further 3 months. That's not all the compers, they do have a core team, but that is a small percentage of the main comp team. Our last extension was 5 months. Which is the end of June, but if those projects coming up in July and August get delayed for vfx, they let us go unfortunately. A lot of the big comanies clear out when there is no more work, the most famous being MPC. 3D are a bit safer, especially animators, but comp are always the first to go.
is the issue for those photos you sent that the patches dont track? Or that the patches get cut off?
Also it looks as if Axis is looking for compers, it's in Bristol but they work on some good stuff. Have you tried them yet?

Struggle to get my head round not having the long term permanence you get with most skilled jobs. Must make planning life pretty tricky.  Heard about MPC in Vancouver recently, pretty devastating but I think the industry's bounced back there.
What's the longest you've been without work since you started working? The 2 weeks you mentioned before? Is the impermanence something you just get used to or ar you always on the lookout for a 'permanent' position, or don't they even exist?

I've known going in about the short term nature of the work and figured experience at good studios with a good reel does the job of propelling people from contract to contract. Although the situation now might be very different. But we're all still consuming hundreds of hours of content at home I so can't believe episodic and regular tv work will dry up completely...but what do I know!

As for monkey shot - everything working well. I need to color match and sort out the shadows. My patch only works for the part of the sequence where that frame hold is in shot. I'm trying to frame hold two frames and switch when the redundant one goes out of shot. I'll upload to Vimeo to see if it makes better sense there. And typing this has given me an idea to try out!

I thought when I looked into getting into the industry that things would be a lot more stable and long term than they actually are. No one really tells you what it is like at these talks and presentations, it is only if you talk to artists working that you really find out what the industry is like. I had no idea about freelance and all that. The longest I've been without work was a month. Happened 3 times. First time in my second year, I finished at jellyfish, didn't have many contacts and could not find work. So I took work as roto prep at One of Us after a friend got me in (keep making contacts at places, especially in the early stages this will help you get other jobs, make as many contacts as possible!). That lasted 3 months, they offered me and extension to work on Assasins Creed but then I got work at Lexhag as a compositor (connected through another friend from film school who recommended me). That was great, got me great work and great cg shots for my showreel. But that ran out end of Nov, that year they were recruiting for Pirates 5 or something at MPC, but I missed that recruitment even though people who weren't as good as me got jobs there and they progressed a lot faster after that. Working at big companies, people will always be impressed by that even if you aren't as good . It was quite frustrating for me for a long time. It was in my third year after working for Lexhag again (I've worked for them 3 or 4 times now I think) that after Poldark they ran out of work, got the Glassworks job but there was a 2 week delay. Then when that job was about to start, they delayed because the work wasn't ready, then a week later they told me the job was cancelled. So I'm now scrambling looking for work after nothing for 3 weeks, then another week goes by and almost about to take work out of london and suddenly Glassworks is back on again. Only 1 month with a possible extension at the end. I hated that job, their first time working in tv (they were normally commercials), I got a few offers after applying and got Bluebolt for 4 months. Bluebolt I got extended for a year 2 months into the contract which was great and very reassuring I was doing the right thing. Then 10 months later, 4 months before the contract was due to end they ran out of work like a lot of places at that time so they let me and 70% of the compers go with a months notice. I got work at Lexhag, but they cancelled less than a week before I was due to start. But a friend who I had previously worked with at Lexhag got me work at Peerless. That was month to month. Lasted 4 months then found out a week before xmas I was being let go. That was the end of my fourth year working. Then we come to last year, got some work at Lexhag, they wanted me back for a couple of months. Did a quick commercial job during that time which also shafted me with pencil dates. Lexhag lasted til end of April, they ran out of work, I moved to Technicolor (again through a friend recommending me). That went for 2 months, and I was renewed there in July through to xmas, but I had applied ILM not thinking I'd get in (Framestore had turned me down the year before for Avengers so I thought I had no chance with ILM). Surprisingly got the job at ILM, 2 months on Mandalorion. Took it and hoped for an extension. At the end they offered me another 2 weeks, with possibly more after that. I couldn't take the chance, but now after working at ILM a lot of people were suddenly answering my applications now. Got a quick interview at Framestore, they gave me an offer very quickly for 3 months and have been extended here twice now.

Its quite a waffling detailed account, but I thought I'd give you a proper idea of how my career has gone so far. Really get to know people and keep in contact, because you hear and get a lot of jobs through people you know. I'm always keeping an eye out for what jobs are around because if work falls through you may be gone, and need to find something quick but you'll also be competing with everyone else who has been let go (and it is rare that just one company lets people go, normally your competing with people from other companies who have just let people go). If I was single I'd be a lot more open to going overseas at short notice, but right now that's not really a reality. But once you get a couple of years experience, there are companies that will pay for your return flight to Canada, visa, your partners flight and visa, and even possibly your first months rent. A lot of places in Canada do that, and Australia. I dont want to scare you by telling you all this, but if I had really known what the industry was like  might have thought twice. While I was at Peerless I had friends who had better showreels asking me to get them in Peerless, because there are apparently periods every couple of years where work dries up everywhere and people find it really hard to find stuff. I find it a bizarre industry, but it's just about being smart and planning ahead. And saving for when things do get quiet.

In regards to permanence, I dont have any friends at my level who have permanent positions. The guy next to me at Framestore has been there 9 years, only place he has worked. The girl on the other side had been there 4 years, but she started in roto prep and was on a very cheap contract. Those are the only 2 people I've known who have permanent contracts. But if you want to stay somewhere, it generally means you wont be making great money compared to people who move around. And there can be huge differences in wages depending how you pitch yourself. But something I've noticed, if you make yourself expensive and work dries up, if you aren't super talented then the expensive ones are usually the ones to go first.

Me starting did of course happen before the streaming boom, but even last year in London as soon as Cats was done, all the compers (on really big contracts) were let go. Even a lot of the streaming contracts right now at smaller companies are only for a couple of months

Wow...thanks for sharing that. Sounds like fraught times and uncertainty are just the nature of the industry. Thing is I like the work and I want to learn and improve more. I’ve no idea where my talent lies atm. 

But is it worth the trouble, and expense to find myself (@43 yrs old) repeatedly unemployed in slumps over many years.  Keep wondering if I’m better off going off to retrain as a plumber or something. Lost Boys will cost circa £23k plus expenses with no guarantee of anything at the end! And Escape cost £10k from what used to be me and my ex’s home. My vfx friends are horrified that I’m spending or even considering spending a penny more than Escape. 

As you know my big idea was to study and make a totally fresh start in Canada but it sounds like they have exactly the same working conditions- the same precarious contracts youve experienced - plus minimal holiday time compared to U.K. - lol.  Having read what you say, I reckon the placement figures for employment the school gives sound impressive but maybe don’t give the more realistic picture of inconsistency of employment that’s actually  the case. 

I’m lucky that I’ll have a nest egg from the house sale :crossed_fingers:and decent settlement for a few years. To be honest I would happily work for free just for the experience. but I’m super keen to get a foothold in a career without leaving everything to chance or luck or the whims of recruiters. 

I was thinking of hacking the system to find myself and mates in the same position work by setting up an app for small scale productions (like indies) to find compers for small scale work - like the cleanup you found me with Alexander. Just a glimmer of an idea but what do you think?  Nuts? 
I’m easily distracted so realise it’s probably procrastination driving that notion! 
Or is it better to specialise - as a colourist or editor or  matte painter or in CG lighting?

No idea what the right thing to do is, especially now, but I guess all our journeys are different and I just have to start... and at least Lost Boys will give me good connections in my fellow students in another country...

Anyway hope Framestore is letting you work from home and that the ILM magic keeps bringing good luck. I really thought a couple of good solid shows brought security and employers trust / commitment to much longer or permanent contracts.  Have to take the view that’s it’s a skilled but seasonal job with an uncertain income I guess, and think about a side hustle of some kind...
